content:
• Wednesday, August 30, 2017
  • CMCSA

    Comcast sues Vermont PUC over franchise conditions

    • Comcast (CMCSA +1.6%) has sued Vermont's Public Utilities Commission, a month after the agency denied a request to lighten the requirements in its franchise agreement.
    • The company requested the removal of requirements tied to network expansion and to public educational and government channels, but the PUC rebuffed the request.
    • Comcast says integrating the PEG channels into its interactive guide (not just the scrolling program grid) could cost $4M, and that customers don't want to pay for that.
    • It's also objecting to a requirement to build out 550 miles of new cable; Comcast says the conditions "contravene federal and state law, amount to undue speaker-based burdens on Comcast’s protected speech under the First Amendment."
     
     
     
     
    | 6:50 PM | 5 Comments
  • CTRP

    Ctrip.com beats by $0.02, beats on revenue

    • Ctrip.com (NASDAQ:CTRP): Q2 EPS of $0.22 beats by $0.02.
    • Revenue of $953.13M (+43.9% Y/Y) beats by $8.06M.
    • Shares +1.99% AH.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:04 PM | 16 Comments
  • DRYS

    DryShips -20% after huge Q2 loss, SEC subpoena

    • DryShips (NASDAQ:DRYS) -20.4% AH after reporting a massive Q2 loss and revealing that it received a subpoena from the SEC for information related to its huge sale of stock between June 2016 and July 2017.
    • The dates include the period in which DRYS issued $700M in new shares, which wiped out the value of stock held by thousands of small investors.
    • DRYS used the proceeds from the offerings to purchase 17 vessels, including five controlled by companies associated with Chairman and CEO George Economou, who earns management fees on the company’s fleet.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:43 PM | 72 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: SCVL +12.9%. KL +5.0%. APEN +4.9%. MOMO +3.1%. BKS +2.8%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: SMTC -12.2%. NRP -4.3%. BOX -3.2%. GGB -1.4%. ENLK -1.3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 4 Comments
  • ANGI

    Angie's List sets date for vote on IAC buyout

    • The S-4 statement for the acquisition of Angie's List (ANGI -2.4%) by IAC/InterActiveCorp (IAC +0.9%) has been declared effective, and Angie's List has set the date for a special meeting.
    • The close of business on Aug. 25 is the record date for a special shareholder meeting scheduled for Sept. 29 at 10 a.m. ET in Indianapolis.
    • Shareholders will take up the buyout as well as a nonbinding vote on executive compensation. IAC plans to combine Angie's List with its HomeAdvisor and create a new publicly traded company, ANGI Homeservices Inc.
    • Angie's List expects the deal to close in late Q3 or early Q4.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:19 PM
  • TEVA

    FDA OKs Teva's Austedo for tardive dyskinesia; shares ahead 1% after hours

    • Teva Pharmaceutical Industries (NYSE:TEVA) announces the FDA approval of AUSTEDO (deutetrabenazine)  for the treatment of adults with tardive dyskinesia, a neurological disorder characterized by stiff jerky uncontrollable movements.
    • The FDA approved the drug in April for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington's disease.
    • Shares are up 1% after hours on average volume.
    • Update: Shares are up 5% on Thursday in early trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:52 PM | 43 Comments
  • BOX

    Box shares slip 2% despite Q2 beats

    • Box (NYSE:BOX) shares are down 2% aftermarket after reporting Q2 results with an EPS beat and narrow revenue beat with sales rising 28.5% on the prior year’s quarter. Guidance for Q3 has revenue from $128M to $129M, which matches consensus at the low end, and loss per share from $0.14 to $0.13 matching at the high end. For the FY18, revenue straddles estimates at $128M to $129M and meets loss per share at the low end from $0.46 to $0.44.
    • Key metrics: Billings were up 31% to $139.5M. Customer count was up to over 76K businesses with new clients including Credit Karma, Cabot Energy, and Delta Global Services.
    • Key financials: Non-GAAP operating expenses totaled $129M, up 22% on the year. Net cash used in operating activities was $9.5M, up from the $4.9M last year. FCF was -$14.7M compared to -$8M. The company ended the quarter with $165M in cash and equivalents.
    • Press release
    • Correction: updated Q2 to revenue beat instead of miss
    • Previously: Box beats by $0.02, beats on revenue (Aug. 30)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:44 PM | 3 Comments
  • VVUS

    Vivus settles Qsymia patent fight with Dr. Reddy's, generic version allowed June 1, 2025; shares up 1% after hours

    • Vivus (NASDAQ:VVUS) is up 1% after hours on light volume on the heels of its Qysmia (phentermine and topiramate extended-release) patent infringement litigation settlement with Dr. Reddy's Laboratories (NYSE:RDY). The settlement agreement allows Dr. Reddy's to sell a generic version on June 1, 2025 or earlier under certain circumstances. If earlier, Vivus will receive a royalty on the sales of the generic.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:27 PM | 3 Comments
  • APEN

    Apollo's ORBERA365 CE Mark'd; shares up 3% after hours

    • Apollo Endosurgery (NASDAQ:APEN) announces the CE Mark certification of its ORBERA365 Managed Weight Loss System. Commercial launch will commence in Q4.
    • ORBERA365 is a non-surgical weight loss intervention to treat obesity. A deflated balloon is placed into the stomach via endoscope then filled with saline until it is the size of a grapefruit. After up to 12 months, the balloon is deflated and removed.
    • Shares are up 3% after hours on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM | 4 Comments
  • FIVE

    Fidget spinners a boost for Five Below

    • Five Below (NASDAQ:FIVE) report comparable sales rose 9.3% in Q2 to sail past the 6.7% mark anticipated by analysts.
    • "We saw solid broad-based performance across our worlds, with notable contribution from the spinner trend," says CEO Joel Anderson.
    • Net income improved 71% Y/Y to $16.8M for the quarter as margins expanded.
    • Looking ahead, the retailer sees full year sales of $1.24B to $1.25B and EPS of $1.62 to $1.66 vs. $1.30 consensus.
    • FIVE +3.21% premarket to $50.85.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:11 PM | 8 Comments
  • FIVE

    Five Below beats by $0.04, beats on revenue

    • Five Below (NASDAQ:FIVE): Q2 EPS of $0.30 beats by $0.04.
    • Revenue of $283.3M (+28.7% Y/Y) beats by $6.66M.
    • Shares +6.5%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:02 PM | 3 Comments
  • CSCO

    BroadSoft shares up 10.9% on sale talks

    • Software company BroadSoft (BSFT) is exploring strategic options including a possible sale, according to Reuters sources.
    • BroadSoft’s Q2 results included $88.8M in revenue, up 9% on the year, and a $3M net loss as the company struggles to compete with the likes of Cisco Systems and Ericsson.
    • Jefferies is assisting with the search for a potential seller or alternate strategy. 
    • BroadSoft shares are up 10.86%.  
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM
  • X

    Steelmakers gain on talk over Houston scrap supplies

    • U.S. Steel (X +3.6%), AK Steel (AKS +4.8%), Nucor (NUE +1.3%) and Steel Dynamics (STLD +1%) are higher amid speculation that flooded scrap yards in Houston could pinch steel supplies in the U.S. (NYSEARCA:SLX)
    • “People are looking at the potential for extra steel demand from a bunch of scrap yards that are all flooded and out of commission, so tightening scrap in that region could help steel prices,” Clarksons Platou analyst Lee McMillan tells Bloomberg, adding that “historically, mini mills have looked to pass on higher scrap prices to customers."
    • McMillan estimates that ~200K automobiles and many appliances will be junked because of Harvey-related flooding, saying "there’s some incremental steel demand that will come of this - we just don’t know how much."
    • KeyBanc's Philip Gibbs also sees U.S. ferrous metals including steel getting a boost in prices, as Houston handles 30%-35% of U.S. steel imports, creating a "relative tactical positive" for steel companies.
    • Also: CLF +4.5%, CMC +3%, MT +1.2%, RS +1.3%.
    • Source: Bloomberg First Word
     
     
     
     
    | 3:40 PM | 25 Comments
  • SBGI

    Sinclair Broadcast renews five Fox affiliation deals; shares +7.2%

    • Sinclair Broadcast Group (NASDAQ:SBGI) has jumped 7.2% after setting an affiliation renewal deal with Fox (FOX +0.4%, FOXA +0.5%) for all five of its stations that had come to the end of their terms.
    • The company renewed Fox affiliations for WACH in Columbia, S.C.; KFOX in El Paso, Texas; KRXI in Reno, Nev.; WFXL in Albany, Ga.; and WSBT in South Bend, Ind.
    • The deal includes participation in vMVPD deals, Sinclair's Barry Faber says.
    • Other affiliations with Fox are up at the end of 2017 and in 2018.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:26 PM | 2 Comments
  • BETR

    Amplify Snack Brands pops on buyout talk

    • Amplify Snack Brands (BETR +3%) shoots higher on a volume spike after sitting in negative territory.
    • Shares made their upward turn after Dealreporter tipped that the food company is pursuing a sale with the assistance of Jefferies.
    • Amplify trades down 18% for the year.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM

  • Technology - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2:55 pm

    • Losers: NH -6%. SMCI -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:56 PM
  • MPC

    Marathon Petroleum, Buckeye Partners said to restart Texas refineries

    • Marathon Petroleum (MPC +2%) reportedly is restarting its 459K bbl/day Galveston Bay refinery after it was shut by Tropical Storm Harvey.
    • Energy industry intelligence service Genscape says one of the refinery’s two 225K bbl/day crude distillation units appears to have restarted based on an observation of activity levels at the unit.
    • Also, Buckeye Partners (BPL -0.2%) is said to have re-started its Corpus Christi terminal after shutting down due to Harvey.
    • Total (TOT -0.6%) expects water within its 225K bbl/day Port Arthur refinery to recede by the weekend, according to a separate report.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:14 PM | 1 Comment
  • NFLX

    Netflix +3% after Bernstein dismisses Disney loss impact

    • No Disney, no worries for Netflix says Bernstein in backing its Overweight rating on the streamer.
    • "Almost all of Netflix's future growth will come from international … Investors who were already skeptical (or bullish) on int'l growth will remain so – but Disney's U.S. non-renewal should have no effect on that view," says analyst Todd Juenger.
    • "In the U.S., recent news flow has, if anything, made us more bullish," he adds.
    • Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) is up 3.10% on the day.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:06 PM | 24 Comments

  • Energy/Materials - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: CLMT +15%. CGG-OLD +13%. ZN +11%. NRP +9%. FMSA +8%.
    • Losers: XCO -11%. PGLC -9%. TTI -8%. BRS -7%. MBII -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM
  • BLUE

    bluebird bio follows through, up 12%

    • The market's enthusiasm for CAR-T developers after Gilead's announced takeover of Kite Pharma has not left bluebird bio (BLUE +11.6%) behind. Shares are up on 44% higher volume, following through on its Monday breakout from brief consolidation. The 52-week (and then some) high is $123.75, reached on June 22.
    • The company's lead CAR-T candidate is bb2121, in Stage 1 development for multiple myeloma.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:22 PM | 1 Comment
  • FRAN

    Francesca's earnings setting up to be volatile event

    • Downside put options on Francesca's (FRAN +0.1%) are the most active in the U.S., according to Bloomberg data.
    • The bets on Francesca's set up the company's earnings report on September 6 to be a high-volatility event. The retailer is expected to report Q2 revenue of $126M and EPS of $0.27.
    • Shares of Francesca's are already down 22% over the last month.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:16 PM
  • FRO

    Frontline -7% after Q2 loss and seeing weak quarters ahead

    • Frontline (FRO -7.6%) sinks near 52-week lows after reporting a larger than expected Q2 loss and warning of difficult upcoming quarters.
    • FRO says the market for its tankers likely would remain weak for the next few quarters due to overcapacity before beginning to improve in 2018, as the pace of deliveries of new vessels slows and older ships are retired from the global fleet.
    • Despite abandoning its effort to buy rival tanker firm DHT Holdings in June, CEO Robert Hvide Macleod says FRO will continue to watch for "attractive opportunities to emerge as a result of the weak market and will remain opportunistic going forward."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:52 PM | 2 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: LINU-OLD +22%. TCON +18%. AVAV +16%. MARK +15%. NBEV +14%. ITCI +14%. QRHC +14%. VSTM +13%. OLED +13%. IMGN +13%.
    • Losers: OTIC -82%. ROKA -32%. OTC:RTNB -27%. BNED -14%. OTCQB:IMNP -14%. XCO -13%. VRA -11%. DY -9%. HTGM -8%. MBII -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM
  • I

    Intelsat prepares to launch fifth next-gen satellite

    • Intelsat (I -1.8%) is readying the launch of the fifth of its next-generation satellites.
    • The company and Arianespace will launch Intelsat 37e, its latest high-throughput satellite, on Sept. 5 in French Guiana.
    • Its Boeing-made payload has full-beam interconnectivity in the C, Ku and Ka bands along with power-sharing and steerable beams in Ku and Ka bands.
    • The satellite will replace Intelsat 901, which will be repositioned.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:22 PM
  • BIIB

    Biogen clears consolidation but volume light, shares up 4%

    • In a post for chartists, Biogen (BIIB +3.6%) breaks out from a six-month base albeit on light volume.
    • Two days ago, it announced positive early-stage data on Alzheimer's candidate aducanumab. Last Friday, the European Commission approved its Humira biosimilar IMRALDI.
    • Previously: Biogen's Alzheimer's candidate aducanumab shows long-term treatment effect in extension phase of early-stage study (Aug. 28)
    • Previously: Biogen's Humira biosimilar OK'd in Europe (Aug. 25)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:15 PM
  • SIX

    Hilliard Lyons sees clear skies for Six Flags

    • Hilliard Lyons upgrades Six Flags Entertainment (SIX +1.6%) to a Buy rating on its view that investors are underestimating the long-term story.
    • We feel adverse weather has been the main reason for the share price weakness, despite having little to no correlation to future years," observes analyst Jeff Thomison.
    • Shares of Six Flags peaked in April at $65.19.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:14 PM | 5 Comments
  • GILD

    Investors acknowledge value of Gilead's takeout of Kite Pharma, shares up 6%

    • In a bit of a delayed response, buying has picked up in Gilead Sciences (GILD +5.5%) two days after it announced that it will acquire Kite Pharma (KITE +0.1%) for $180/share ($11.9B). Volume is 70% above normal.
    • Gilead shares rose a modest 1% the day of the announcement and 1% the day after.
    • The announcement by Novartis that it has priced just-approved CAR-T Kymriah at $475K has certainly contributed to the bullishness since it bodes well for Kite's CAR-T axicabtagene ciloleucel.
    • Previously: Gilead takes out Kite Pharma for $11.9B in cash; Kite up 16% premarket (Aug. 28)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:03 PM | 29 Comments

  • Consumer - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: NBEV +19%. REED +10%. SGOC +10%. CAL +9%. SUMR +6%.
    • Losers: VRA -8%. BETR -6%. WILC -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM
  • ALSN

    Piper Jaffray warns of EV impact on Allison Transmission

    • Allison Transmission (ALSN -4%) trades lower after Piper Jaffray lowers its price target on the Underweight-rated stock to $25.
    • "Electrification represents a secular threat, with near/medium term disruption in bus and refuse markets likely to eventually spread to all of ALSN’s targeted segments," warns analyst Alexander Potter.
    • Shares of Allison Transmission are down 12% over the last 90 days.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:28 AM
  • KHC

    Buffett doesn't see Kraft-Mondelez mega food deal

    • CNBC asked Warren Buffett if he expected Kraft Heinz (KHC +0.5%) to make a run at acquiring Mondelez International (MDLZ -0.3%).
    • "I think the answer is no on that," responded Buffett.
    • Kraft and Mondelez have been linked in M&A speculation since the Kraft-Heinz merger.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:18 AM | 18 Comments

  • Healthcare - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 11:10 am

    • Gainers: IMGN +13%. MZOR +12%. CRBP +12%. NBRV +10%. VSTM +10%.
    • Losers: OTIC -80%. ROKA -37%. OTCQB:IMNP -13%. ALT -9%. CUR -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:12 AM | 5 Comments
  • NVS

    FDA OKs Novartis' CAR-T for ALL

    • As expected, the FDA approves Novartis' (NVS -0.9%) Kymriah (tisagenlecleucel), a CAR-T immunotherapy for treatment-resistant B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the first CAR-T approved in the U.S. for any indication.
    • The company says it plans to file marketing applications in the U.S. and Europe later this year for adult patients with relapsed/refractory diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
    • The FDA also approved the use of Roche's (OTCQX:RHHBY) Actemra (tocilizumab) to treat CAR-T-induced severe or life-threatening cytokine release syndrome (CRS), a common adverse event with the therapy.
    • Previously: FDA Ad Com unanimously backs Novartis' CAR-T for ALL; shares up 2% (July 12)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:56 AM | 6 Comments
  • CAL

    Caleres soars after strong Q2

    • Caleres (CAL +9.9%) trades higher after blowing past Q2 estimates.
    • The retailer recorded a 2.8% gain in comparable sales at Famous Footwear and saw gross margin arrive at 42.5% of sales vs. 41.9% consensus estimate.
    • Susquehanna sticks with a Positive rating on Caleres after taking in the annual guidance, noting that management was probably conservative with the full extent of Hurricane Harvey's impact on August sales not yet known.
    • Previously: Caleres beats by $0.04, beats on revenue (Aug. 29)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:47 AM
  • QCOM

    Qualcomm and Himax announce 3D sensor collab; QCOM joins IoT alliance

    • Qualcomm (NASDAQ:QCOM) and Himax Technologies (NASDAQ:HIMX) announce a collaboration to develop and commercialize high-res, low power active 3D depth sensing camera systems.
    • The systems will enable computer vision capabilities including face authentication and scene perception across a range of industries including automotive, virtual reality, and IoT. 
    • The collaboration combines Qualcomm’s Spectra tech and computer vision architecture with Himax’s wafer optics, sensor, and driver technologies. 
    • In related news, Qualcomm joins the IoT Cybersecurity Alliance that also includes Palo Alto Networks, IBM, and Symantec. 
    • Qualcomm shares are up 0.40%. 
    • Himax Technologies shares are up 2.9%.  
     
     
     
     
    | 10:38 AM | 38 Comments
  • ROKA

    Roka files preliminary proxy for asset sale to IEH and liquidation of company; shares down 36%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Roka Bioscience (ROKA -36.4%) slumps on an 8x surge in volume in early trading. Yesterday evening, it filed its preliminary proxy statement for the special shareholders meeting during which it will seek approval for the previously announced $17.5M asset sale to Institute for Environmental Health (IEH) and liquidation.
    • Previously: Roka Bio proceeds with liquidation, agrees to sell all assets for $17.5M (Aug. 17)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:37 AM

  • EIA Petroleum Inventories

    • EIA Petroleum Inventories: Crude -5.4M barrels vs. -1.9M consensus, -3.3M last week.
    • Gasoline Unchanged vs. -0.9M consensus, -1.2M last week.
    • Distillates +0.7M barrels vs. -0.8M consensus, +0.0M last week.
    • Futures -0.69% to $46.12.
    • ETFs:USO, OIL, UCO, SCO, BNO, DTO, DBO, USL, DNO, SZO, OLO, OLEM
     
     
     
     
    | 10:31 AM | 109 Comments
  • SFM

    Volatile trading on Sprouts Farmers Market

    • Sprouts Farmers Market (NASDAQ:SFM) is up 1.86% on heavy volume with some M&A chatter floating around trading desks.
    • Yesterday, call options activity was elevated on Sprouts. Bloomberg reports total call volume was 7X the 20-day average.
    • Shares of Sprouts are still down 18% since Amazon fired off notice last week of lower prices at Whole Foods.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:04 AM | 11 Comments
  • EROS

    Eros, Micromax offering content-filled tablet to India

    • Eros Now (EROS +1.6%), the streaming service of Eros International (NYSE:EROS), and Micromax Informatics are coming together on a content-filled tablet for the Indian market.
    • The tablet, Canvas Plex, will offer users a year's premium subscription and feature an 8-inch HD screen along with 3 GB of RAM, 32 GB of ROM and DTS sound.
    • It's launching Sept. 1 at a price of 12,999 rupees (about $203).
    • The two companies will also team up to promote upcoming Bollywood film Shubh Mangal Saavdhan, with some consumers winning VIP access to the film's stars.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:50 AM
  • VEON

    Veon +2.4% on $940M sale of Pakistan towers

    • Veon (NASDAQ:VEON) is up 2.4% premarket after it and Global Telecom Holding reached a deal for their Pakistan unit Jazz to sell its tower business, Deodar, for about $940M.
    • The deal was reported to be getting closer yesterday.
    • The buyer, Tanzanite Tower Limited, is owned by Edotco Group (Axiata) and Dawood Hercules. It gets about 13,000 towers in the deal.
    • The enterprise value comes to a high single-digit multiple of combined annual EBITDA, a significant premium, Veon says.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:25 AM | 1 Comment
  • DY

    Dycom -12% following revenue miss, weakened guidance

    • Dycom Industries (NYSE:DY) -12.1% premarket after reporting better than expected FQ4 earnings, as contract revenues fell to $780M from $789M a year ago and coming in below the analyst consensus of $799M.
    • DY issues downside guidance for FQ1, seeing EPS of $0.81-$0.96, far short of the $1.43 consensus estimate, on contract revenues of $715M-$745M, below the $785M consensus.
    • FBR Capital nevertheless reiterates its Buy recommendation, continuing to see DY as uniquely positioned to benefit from a massive upgrade to the wireline infrastructure in the U.S. over the next five-plus years and in the next wireless network upgrade cycle, which the firm expects to start in 2018 (source: Briefing.com).
     
     
     
     
    | 9:21 AM | 1 Comment

  • Premarket Losers as of 9:05 am

    • OTIC -82% on reporting results for AVERTS-1 Phase 3 trial for OTIVIDEX in patients with Meniere disease.
    • DY -14% on Q2 earnings.
    • CHS -9% on Q2 earnings.
    • OTC:RTNB -8%.
    • HRB -6% on Q2 earnings.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:10 AM
  • BNED

    Weak textbook sales at Barnes & Noble Education

    • Barnes & Noble Education (NYSE:BNED) heads lower in premarket trading after the company falls short of estimates with FQ1 revenue.
    • College comparable store sales fell 2.5% during the quarter. Textbook sales were down 8.5%.
    • Looking ahead, Barnes & Noble Education sees consolidated sales falling in a range of $2.25B to $2.35B.
    • Previously: Barnes & Noble Education misses on revenue (Aug. 30)
    • BNED -8.36% premarket to $6.25.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:00 AM
  • TTOO

    T2 Biosystems announces 11 new patents granted in 2017; shares ahead 8% premarket

    • T2 Biosystems (NASDAQ:TTOO) announces that it has been granted 11 new patents in 2017 that further broaden and strengthen the protection around the T2 Magnetic Resonance (T2MR) platform, including the T2Sepsis Solution and hemostasis technology. With the grant of these new patents, T2 Biosystems now owns or licenses over 60 patents.
    • Highlights of patents granted in 2017 are as follows:
    • Two patents cover the method and use of certain reagents for the company’s primary diagnostic products that run on the T2Dx Instrument and support the T2Sepsis Solution.
    • Two patents cover the method and design of the automated sample lysis process.
    • One patent broadens the company’s portfolio of T2MR detector patents for small, portable magnetic resonance detection devices.
    • One patent represents new intellectual property that covers an innovative method of integrating fluidics.
    • One patent covers probe sequences that can be used for high sensitivity detection of Candida species.
    • Four patents cover methods in the area of hemostasis.
    • The other patents in T2 Biosystems’ patent portfolio include patents with claims covering technical innovations.
    • Shares are up 8% premarket on light volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:48 AM
  • ADI

    Analog Devices up 4.1% after Q3, guidance beats

    • Analog Devices (NASDAQ:ADI) shares are up 4.1% premarket after reporting Q3 results with EPS and revenue beats with revenue up over 64% on the year. Fourth quarter guidance has revenue from $1.45B to $1.55B, matching consensus on the lower end, and EPS from $1.29 to $1.43, above the $1.24 consensus. Gross margin expected at 70.5% and operating margin around 42%.
    • End market revenue: Industrial, $700M (+87%); Automotive, $227.5M (+69%); Consumer, $252.5M (+36%); Communications, $253.7M (+45%). 
    • Key financials: Gross margin (non-GAAP) was 70.5%, up from 66% in last year’s quarter and from 69.3% in Q2. Operating expenses were $437M and the company ended the quarter with $908.6M in cash and equivalents.    
    • Press release     
    • Previously: Analog Devices declares $0.45 dividend (Aug. 30)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:40 AM | 6 Comments
  • VBIV

    VBI Vaccines on go with late-stage study of Sci-B-Vac; shares ahead 6% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap VBI Vaccines (NASDAQ:VBIV) is up 6% premarket on light volume in response to its announcement that the FDA has signed off on its IND for a Phase 3 program evaluating hepatitis B vaccine candidate Sci-B-Vac.
    • Health Canada is on board as well. A U.S./Canada clinical trial will commence later this year across ~40 sites.
    • See important disclosures.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:38 AM
  • SBGL

    Sibanye Gold swings to H1 loss, cancels dividend for first time

    • Sibanye Gold (NYSE:SBGL) -4% premarket after canceling its dividend amid a $364M H1 loss, citing impairments and provisions for an expected settlement with miners who contracted lung diseases at work.
    • SBGL says it will focus on cutting debt after its $2.2B purchase of Stillwater Mining earlier this year, making the payment of a cash dividend “inappropriate.”
    • A class action lawsuit, mostly relating to the fatal lung disease silicosis, was filed on behalf of miners in 2012 and has led several companies to increase provisions related to the health and safety conditions.
    • The company also says it will change its name to Sibanye-Stillwater.

  • VRA

  • MDT

    Mazor Robotics and Medtronic enter next phase of strategic partnership; shares of Mazor up 6% premarket

    • Mazor Robotics (NASDAQ:MZOR) announces that it has entered the next phase of its strategic partnership with Medtronic (NYSE:MDT) earlier than planned.
    • Key highlights of the agreement are as follows:
    • Medtronic assumes exclusive global spine market commercial responsibility for the Mazor X Surgical Assurance Platform and its accessories.
    • The implementation of annual minimums for purchase of Mazor X systems by Medtronic with a cumulative potential of hundreds of Mazor X systems over a four and a half-year period.
    • Approximately 30 Mazor salespeople will join Medtronic to assure continuation of the current momentum.
    • Medtronic will invest $40M in Mazor at $38.46 per ADS. This third tranche of investment will bring Medtronic’s total investment in Mazor to $72M, representing ~11.9% of the outstanding shares post investment and 10.6% of the fully diluted shares.
    • Mazor will also issue to Medtronic warrants to purchase an additional 1.21M Mazor ADSs at an exercise price of $44.23 per ADS representing 15% premium. Medtronic has the right to exercise the warrants immediately in whole or in part, for cash, and they expire after 18 months. Assuming the full exercise of the warrants, Medtronic’s investment in Mazor will reach $125M and its ownership could increase to 4.2M ADSs, or 14.2%. Closing date of the $40M equity investment is September 12.
    • Mazor will continue to independently develop and market globally the Renaissance Surgical Guidance System.
    • The Company will host a conference call at 8:30 AM ET.
    • Shares are up 6% premarket on modest volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:03 AM | 25 Comments

  • LLY

    Lilly to refile U.S. marketing application for RA med baricitinib in January 2018

    • Eli Lilly (NYSE:LLY) gives shareholders some good news this morning with its announcement that, after discussions with the FDA, it plans to resubmit its New Drug Application (NDA) for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) med baricitinib by the end of January 2018. The refiling will include new safety and efficacy data.
    • The company received a CRL in April citing the need for additional clinical data to support the optimum doses and additional data to further characterize the safety profile across treatment arms.
    • In July, the company said it did not anticipate refiling for at least 18 months. It also believes the FDA will regard it as a Class II resubmission which has a six-month review cycle.
    • Lilly co-developed baricitinib, an oral JAK inhibitor, with Incyte (NASDAQ:INCY), under a December 2009 agreement. It was approved in Europe in February and Japan in July.
    • Previously: FDA rejects Lilly's marketing application for RA candidate baricitinib (April 14)
    • Previously: Refiling of U.S. marketing application for arthritis med baricitinib at least 18 months away, Lilly down 1%, Incyte down 4% premarket (July 25)
    • Update: LLY is up 3% and INCY 8% mid-session.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:40 AM | 11 Comments
  • OTIC

    Otonomy's Otividex flunks late-stage study in Ménière’s disease

    • A Phase 3 clinical trial, AVERTS-1, assessing Otonomy's (NASDAQ:OTIC) OTIVIDEX in patients with an inner ear disorder called Ménière’s disease failed to achieve its primary endpoint of a statistically valid reduction in the number of vertigo days from baseline compared to placebo (58% vs. 55%; p=0.62). The study also failed to achieve any of the key secondary vertigo endpoints.
    • CEO David Weber, Ph.D., says, “We are greatly disappointed by these results, and surprised by both the higher placebo response and lower OTIVIDEX improvement than observed in our previous trials. I would like to thank the many patients and investigators who participated in our Ménière’s clinical program. Based on these results, we are immediately suspending all development activities for OTIVIDEX including the ongoing AVERTS-2 trial. In addition, the company is undertaking a review of its product pipeline and commercial efforts to identify opportunities to extend its cash runway and build shareholder value."
    • OTIVIDEX (formerly OTO-104), a sustained-exposure formulation of the steroid dexamethasone, was being developed to treat a range of balance and hearing disorders. It is administered directly into the middle ear via injection through the eardrum.
    • The company is withdrawing its previously announced spending guidance for 2017 of $80M - 85M. As of June 30, its cash balance was $150.5M.
    • Management will host a conference call this morning at 8:00 am ET to discuss the results.
    • Nasdaq has not listed the premarket trading activity yet, but shareholders should expect a significant down move.
    • Update: Shares are down 71% in initial trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:23 AM | 8 Comments
